content.body: Me too, given that an iframe pointint to a C-D resource can be script-inserted.
this is reference to https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=64580#c51
TabAtkins: exactly
sephr: floating point random numbers are really hard
for one, the range isn't uniform the way developers will typically expect
so is randomizing the bytes not sufficiently cryptographically random?
it doesn't have the distribution that people will normally expect
frex random values in the range [0, 1) will be biased since the epsilon between representable values is non-uniform on that range
I understand that the distrobution may confuse some, but specifically excluding floats doesn't really help for people who honestly want random floats
ok thanks
well when do you want cryptographically random floats?
i don't know of any cryptographic routines that use floating point input values like this
I don't; I was just wondering
lol ok :p
thanks for the explanation
not claiming that i know a lot of crypto stuff
but i think it'll bite people who want secure numbers
btw, Hixie: on the whole text/html-sandboxed thing being insufficient: a "sandbox" directive was added to CSP
so you may or may not want to just remove the text/html-sandboxed registration
http://dvcs.w3.org/hg/content-security-policy/raw-file/tip/csp-specification.dev.html#sandbox
including floats doesn't help people who honestly want random floats :)
did you mean excluding?
no, including
he said excluding doesn't help; i say including doesn't help either
zewt: whar about plain arraybuffers btw?
surely there are times when you want a binary blob and you don't care about it being indexed into a uint8array
you should only use the crypto API when you care about cryptographic properties of the values
jacobolus: think truecrypt's hidden volume impl
jamesr: â†‘ ?
just writing a random blob, not actually using the values in a computation
that's using the data at an array of 8-bit ints
yeah but the file api doesn't take 8 bit int arrays
it takes arraybuffers
I get that getting .buffer is easy enough
which you can create an 8-bit int view for to create the data--the underlying algorithm is using an array of 8-bit ints
there's always a data type associated with data, for any algorithm
well most likely
might be a 7bit filesys though
even though it surely isn't
anyways I get you so ok end of discussion
that's not exactly how discussions work :)
heycam: How should I respond to issues in the SVG issue tracker?
TabAtkins, just send mail on www-svg and include the ISSUE-nnnn in the subject or body of the mail
subject is good, then repliers don't need to remember to reinclude it in the body
(so in fact I should have done that in my mail just now)
(anyway I put a link to the start of the stroke gradient thread in the initial text of the issue, so it doesn't matter too much of other mails in that thread don't get tagged correctly)
heycam: ...huh.  I'm apparently not subscribed to enough of the SVG lists.  I didn't get any of this thread.
TabAtkins, you're not on www-svg?
Apparently not.
huh
Anyway, just subscribed.
so from now on we're trying to do technical discussion on that list rather than public-svg-wg, so it's easier for non-WG members to contribute
Is public-svg-wg not a public list?
Or is it just easier to suscribe to for some reason?
you can read public archives of it, but non WG members can't subscribe to it
Ah, gotcha.  That's silly.
yeah, it's a weird half way compared to other WGs
anyone have any tests for this crazy filename* syntax the http guys are peddling?
julian says everyone implements it
Link?
whatwg e-mail
Oh, that encoding stuff?
What is this number supposed to refer to?
Do you mean RFC 2231/5987?
TabAtkins: i meant RFC 6266
Hixie, I think Julian made tests
Hixie, http://greenbytes.de/tech/tc2231/
is anyone else enjoying the discussion at http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=13333 ? :-)
that looks like a good bug to avoid reading
annevk5, thanks
Using html5lib i keep getting this error "  File "/usr/lib/pymodules/python2.7/html5lib/inputstream.py", line 50, in seek" "    assert pos < self._bufferedBytes()" "AssertionError"
it's strange as it works on ubuntu 11.04 but not 11.10
same code..
any ideas?
Stevezau: Got some sample input?
I don't have 11.04 handy so I'm not quite sure how I will track it down.
is actually trying to make some fixes to html5lib for the first time in a while
AryehGregor: ping
hsivonen, I'm having trouble checking out the validator source because the w3.org DTDs are timing out, is it possible to skip those if I'm just interested in HTML5?
jgraham nevermind, i tracked it to urllib2
issue with python 2.7.2 latest release
Stevezau: OK
So this sems like a spec bug, but maybe I am not thinking straight
<html><table><math><mi>foo</mi>
AFAICT the foo causes the treebuilder to go into the in table text insertion mode
Which buffers the character tokens
But the </mi> is processed in foreign content which doesn't flush the buffer
so the foo ends up outside the <mi>
Did I miss something?
How do you apply a css class to a strokeRect? (not using the strokestyle, which can only be a css color,canvasgradient,canvaspattern)
You don't
is there a standard way to do animated strokeStyles other than looping through drawImage?
WTF? http://whattf.org/
Yes, WhatTF
adding domintro boxes sucks
yes
a lot of it is just duplicate information phrased slightly differently
i added a few extra to DOM Core though and I guess I will try to complete it
Hixie: i think you enjoy trolling the RDFa folks too much
